speaker: Teacher
text: What was "the cake" in French the word we have in English too?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu le veux?" Very good. In this with this "it", we mean "la baguette", za primer,

speaker: Teacher
text: how would you say this: "do you want it"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu la veux?" Very good. "The confirmation." How was "the confirmation"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. And we have less "n", no? On both of those ends a lot less "n".

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "La confirmation." And those are not pronouncing the "n" kind of keeps the vowel in a different place in the mouth, which is much more French. So, also we will notice you pronounce more French vowels if we don't pronounce those "n's". "La confirmation." So we, we also saw how these "ion", "ion" nouns are feminine, no? And take "la" for "the". And when we refer to them and we say "it", we use "la". How would you say "I want the confirmation"?

speaker: Student
text: Je veux la confirm... Je veux la confirmation.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux la confirmation." "I want it." And we mean "the confirmation."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je la veux." So we've seen how we can access French words from our English, no? Be them odd words that have ended such as "gâteau", "café" or "baguette", for example. Or big groups of words with the same endings, like those "ion" words, ending "ion". With our words ending "ation", so A-T-I-O-N, rather than just "ion". We can do something else which really expands our French with very little effort and allows us to literally make thousands of sentences very easily.

speaker: Student
text: So, whenever we have an "ation" noun, one of those words we put "the" in front of, no? Ending "ation". "The confirmation", "the organization". We can generally find the verb, the word we can put "to" in front of, like "to confirm", "to organize" very easily. So we have "confirmation" for example, "confirmation". And if we want the verb "to confirm", we just get rid of this "ation" and we add "e-r" and this is pronounced "ay". So we get "confirmer".

speaker: Teacher
text: "Confirmer." So that's "to confirm", even though "to confirm" in English is two words, it's just one idea. And that one idea of "to confirm", no? Is one word in French, "confirmer". "Confirmer." So we don't have to worry about remembering the words here, but just how to find them. And like anything, it's very easy to remember how to do it, doing it with a little practice. So, how would you say "celebration" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Célébration." Now, to get "to celebrate" we get rid of this "ation" and we put "e-r" which sounds like "e", "e". So, "to celebrate"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "I want to celebrate." "Do you want to celebrate?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. But the "tu" is a longer vowel and we should project it a little bit more, poking our lips out and rounding them a little bit. "Tu."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Un peu." This is spelled U-N, this U-N is just "uh". We think the N again. We don't pronounce it, we just think about it. It's there, "Uh". Like we're going towards it, but we didn't get there. And then "peu".

speaker: Teacher
text: And "peu" is like "the". The same vowel sound there which we get with E-U. "Un peu." "A little."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Do you want to celebrate a little?"

speaker: Student
text: Tu veux célébr... Tu veux célébrer un peu?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux célébrer un peu?" So, "peu" and "veux" have the same vowel sound, no? Which in both cases is achieved with an EU in writing. How would you say "I want to celebrate a little"? "I want to celebrate a little."

speaker: Student
text: Um. Je veux celeb... Je veux célébrer un peu.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux célébrer un peu." So, if you are speaking and you want to express something like "to reserve", "to invite", you can just check with yourself, do we have an "ation" word in English to say that? "Reservation"? Yes. "Invitation"? Yes. And if so, then you can probably find the verb in French. So, how would you say "participation"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux participer." So the trick here is also realizing that we know these words, no? You may be, you may be wanting to express something like "I want to get involved". And not realize that you can say that in French because you don't think of "to participate" for "to get involved". Now, often the French way of saying things will sound much more formal in English. "I want to participate" sounds more formal than "I want to get involved". Now, but "je veux participer" just sounds like "I want to get involved" in French. It sounds very everyday. So sometimes you'll have to make that jump yourself to find the word you're looking for. "To get involved", oh, is there an "ation" way of saying that? "Participation", ah, okay. "Participer". How would you say "I want to get involved a little?" "I want to get involved a little?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux participer un peu." "You want", just "you want".

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux." "Do you want to get involved?"

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux participer?" "Do you want to get a little involved?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. "Tu veux participer un peu?" And in the same way, "a little" can work its way into the middle there in English now. Uh, "do you want to get a little involved?" We can do the same in French too if we want. "Tu veux un peu participer?" How would you say "I want to visit"? So you would be forgiven for thinking, I can't say that in French. But don't decide too quickly. We have "visitation" in English. We don't use it very often. "Visitation", "visitation rights-"

speaker: Teacher
text: ... for example, for hospital or something. But that's enough to make you suspect that you can find "to visit" in French. So "I want to visit".

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux visiter." "Do you want to visit?"
